title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on lottery winnings or gambling payouts to pay child support arrearages. The distributor must suspend payment, withhold the arrearage amount, and pay it to the child support agency. The amended Social Security Act requires the suspension of payment, withholding of child support arrearage amounts, and payment to the state agency for distribution from insurance policies, claim settlements, and court awards. The amended Social Security Act mandates the suspension of payment, withholding of child support arrearage amounts, and payment to the state agency for distribution from insurance policies, claim settlements, and court awards. The payor must suspend payment until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears, withhold the arrearage amount, and pay it to the state agency. If the state seizes property forfeited due to a criminal conviction, it must hold the property until receiving a response from the state. The State must hold forfeited property until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears, then sell the property and pay the arrearage amount to the State agency for distribution. Any person required to make payment in respect to a decedent must suspend the payment until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears. If there is an arrearage, the person must withhold and pay the amount to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for State licensing departments to withhold licenses from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants and individuals delinquent in child support payments until certain conditions are met. Procedures for State motor vehicle departments to withhold driver's licenses and vehicle registrations from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants, requiring individuals to demonstrate why their licenses should not be suspended. The individual's driver's license or vehicle registration should not be suspended until the warrant is removed by the State responsible for issuing the warrant. Temporary license or vehicle registration may be granted pending compliance with the order or removal of the warrant. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. If the seizure is not successfully challenged, the institution may pay the arrearage amount to the collecting entity. The amended Section 466(a) allows seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. The institution may pay the arrearage amount to the collecting entity. SEC. 5. REPORTING OF CHILD SUPPORT OBLIGATIONS TO CREDIT BUREAUS. Amends Section 466(a)(7) of the Social Security Act to require courts or agencies to report individual names and child support amounts to consumer reporting agencies. SEC. 6. LIABILITY OF GRANDPARENTS FOR FINANCIAL SUPPORT OF THEIR GRANDCHILDREN. SEC. 6. Liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. Amends the Social Security Act to make each parent responsible for supporting their child if the individual is unable to do so.
